title: Renault Slumps as Profit Warning Deepens Auto Industry Gloom
text:
(Bloomberg) -- Renault SA set a gloomy tone for the European automotive sector by slashing its outlook for revenue and profit this year, saying weakening economies are weighing on car sales and tougher rules on emissions have increased costs.

The French carmaker’s shares fell as much as 13% in early trading on Friday after Renault reduced its financial guidance for 2019, citing challenges in markets outside Europe, including Turkey and Argentina, and spending on research and development.

This week interim Chief Executive Officer Clotilde Delbos told employees that the company needs to re-evaluate the strategic road map put in place by former CEO Carlos Ghosn to reflect a change in the industry environment. She wasted no time after taking the helm just a week ago following the ousting of Thierry Bollore, which has further added to disarray at the carmaker also struggling to repair relations with its Japanese partner Nissan Motor Co.

“This profit warning comes at a time of major instability at Renault and its partner Nissan,” Evercore ISI analyst Arndt Ellinghorst wrote in a note. “Investor worries will more likely intensify.”

Delbos on Thursday said the new management team is reassessing the “Drive the Future” mid-term targets unveiled in 2017.

Yet for this year, Renault said revenue will decline by 3% to 4%, after previously forecasting sales would be close to last year’s level. Group operating margin will be around 5%, below previous estimates for 6%. Renault is scheduled to release quarterly sales next week.

The shares fell 12.2%, the most since the arrest of Ghosn in Japan in November, dragging down the rest of the European auto sector. The Stoxx Europe 600 Automobiles & Parts Index dropped 2.7%.

Car sales across Europe have been weak. They declined 1.6% to 12.1 million in the nine months through September, the European Automobile Manufacturers Association said this week. Spain led the decline with a 7.4% drop, with Germany the only major market to record a gain.

The poor outlook for this year for Renault has raised the spectre of more radical surgery at the carmaker.

“We assume a significant cut to the dividend and believe Renault may need to consider selling assets including Nissan shares to defend its balance sheet,” Jefferies analyst Philippe Houchois wrote in a note.

Renault took a hit in the first half of 2019 from poor results at partner Nissan Motor Co. The French automaker owns 43% of the Japanese company, which is forecasting its worst operating profit in a decade, hurt by an aging product lineup and a slide in vehicle sales in the U.S. and Europe.

Having replaced its CEO, one key question when Nissan reports results in early November is whether the new management will take more drastic measures to improve profitability.

Renault’s third-quarter sales fell to 11.3 billion euros ($12.6 billion) from 11.5 billion euros the previous year, the company said. Cash flow should be positive in second half of the year, but may not be for the whole of 2019.

In the video to employees, Delbos said the company need to “make some choices,” highlighting Renault’s negative cash flow in the first six months of the year. “Unfortunately the situation hasn’t improved during the summer and we need to put Renault back on track,” she said.

(Adds shares in second paragraph, analyst comment in third.)
